p: Our models indicate that L. intermedia will become more tropical, while L. neivai will shift southwards and become more subtropical. This contradicts the suggestion that L. whitmani might replace L. intermedia ( s.l.) as the more important vector of L. braziliensis in southern Brazil and nearby Argentina [ 16]. Currently, L. whitmani is likely to share transmission of CL with L. intermedia only in the south-east region of Brazil, such as in Espírito Santo and Minas Gerais [ 9]. In fact, there is no evidence in the past 13 years that L. whitmani has spread into the far south of Brazil, where L. neivai is the only reported vector [ 4, 63]. Our results agree with the previous niche model of L. neivai produced by Maxent for north-west Argentina [ 18]. In Argentina, L. neivai is the most abundant sand fly species in CL transmission areas [ 68], and modelling predicts it will persist there in the future.
